Disease # 13087 - Pediatric acute-onset neuropsychiatric syndrome

Other Names: PANS

Categories:

This disease is grouped under: Pediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorders associated with Streptococcus infections

Summary: Pediatric acute-onset neuropsychiatric syndrome (PANS) is a condition defined by sudden onset of obsessive-compulsive symptoms and/or severe eating restrictions, along with at least two other cognitive, behavioral, or neurological symptoms.[14939] Examples of other symptoms include anxiety, depression, tics, personality changes, decline in school performance, and sensory sensitivities.[14942][14944] Symptoms typically begin during childhood but may begin at any age.[14949] Symptoms may go away for a while and then come back (referred to as a relapsing and remitting course).[14939] However, symptoms may be worse and last longer with each episode.[14950]

PANS is thought to have a variety of possible causes. In more than 80% of cases, there is evidence of an abnormal autoimmune or inflammatory response in the brain following any of various infections in the body.[14939][14943] When the associated infection is known to be strep, the condition is called PANDAS (a subtype of PANS).[14942] Other possible causes of PANS include psychological trauma and underlying autoimmune, neurological, endocrine, or metabolic disorders.[14939] There are likely non-infectious triggers that have not yet been identified.[14942]

The diagnosis of PANS is made only when all other possible causes of symptoms are ruled out (this is a called a diagnosis of exclusion). Depending on the symptoms present, this process may rely on factors such as medical and psychiatric history, a physical exam, evaluation by various specialists, and a variety of tests or imaging studies such as blood tests, an electroencephalogram (EEG), sleep study (polysomnography) and/or brain MRI.[14939]

Treatment depends on the symptoms and severity in each person and may involve improving symptoms with psychiatric medicines and behavioral interventions, treating underlying infections or sources of inflammation with antibiotics, and/or stabilizing the immune system with immunotherapy and/or anti-inflammatory therapies (in immune-related PANS).[14939] Treatment may be tapered down or stopped when symptoms resolve but may be needed again if symptoms return.[14939]

Many people with PANS who undergo treatment show overall improvement over months to years or will recover completely.[14953][14955] However, relapses may still occur after long periods of remission.[14955] Others will have ongoing symptoms that require continuous treatment.[14953] If not treated, PANS can lead to permanent debilitation.[14950] Unfortunately, at this time it is not possible to predict the course of the condition in each person.[14953]

Learn More
  • The National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) has information on this topic. NIMH is part of the National Institutes of Health and is dedicated to understanding, treating, and preventing mental illnesses.
  • KidsHealth from Nemours has an information page on Pediatric acute-onset neuropsychiatric syndrome. Click on the link to access this resource.
  • The PANDAS Physicians Network (PPN) has a Practitioner Directory as an informational resource. The directory includes the names of PPN members who have given their permission to be identified publicly. Inclusion in the directory is not an endorsement or a warranty of the doctors and medical professionals or the care they provide. Practitioners in the directory offer an expertise in a wide range of specialties.
  • Swedo SE, Frankovich J, Murphy TK. Overview of Treatment of Pediatric Acute-Onset Neuropsychiatric Syndrome. J Child Adolesc Psychopharmacol. 2017 Sep 1; 27(7): 562–565.
  • Chang K, Frankovich J, Cooperstock M, et al. Clinical evaluation of youth with pediatric acute-onset neuropsychiatric syndrome (PANS): recommendations from the 2013 PANS Consensus Conference. J Child Adolesc Psychopharmacol. 2015 Feb;25(1):3-13.
  • The PANDAS Physicians Network provides information about PANS and PANDAS.
  • Thienemann M, Murphy T, Leckman J, et al. Clinical Management of Pediatric Acute-Onset Neuropsychiatric Syndrome: Part I—Psychiatric and Behavioral Interventions. J Child Adolesc Psychopharmacol. 2017 Sep 1; 27(7): 566–573.
  • Francovich J, Swedo S, Murphy T, et al. Clinical Management of Pediatric Acute-Onset Neuropsychiatric Syndrome: Part II—Use of Immunomodulatory Therapies. J Child Adolesc Psychopharmacol. 2017 Sept;27(7).
  • Cooperstock MS, Swedo S, Pasternack MS, Murphy TK. Clinical Management of Pediatric Acute-Onset Neuropsychiatric Syndrome: Part III—Treatment and Prevention of Infections. J Child Adolesc Psychopharmacol. 2017 Sept;27(7).
  • The Alliance to Solve PANS & Immune-Related Encephalopathies (ASPIRE) has a Find a Provider directory which includes various types of specialists involved in the diagnosis and treatment of Pediatric acute-onset neuropsychiatric syndrome.
